chapter.title: Liferay Faces Portal Expression Language Additions
chapter.para: Liferay Faces Portal introduces several variables into the Expression Language (EL).

sect1.title: i18n
sect1.para: As an abbreviation for the word "internationalization", the i18n EL variable enables page authors to declaratively specify message keys that are provided by one of the following:

listitem.simpara: Portlet WAR additions to Liferay's Language Utility

sect1.para: The Liferay Language Utility is typically accessed by portlet developers by calling static Java methods found in the LanguageUtil class. The utility operates by reading the locale-specific version of the portal's Language.properties file, which contains thousands of keys and internationalized messages.

Portlet developers can extend the Liferay Language Utility by creating a file within the portlet WAR named WEB-INF/liferay-hook.xml that points to locale-specific resource bundles that are in the runtime classpath of the portlet.

example.title: Usage of the i18n EL Variable

sect1.para: When using JBoss EL, page authors can take advantage of the i18n.replace() method in order to substitute values into the text of the message.

example.title: Usage of the i18n EL Variable with JBoss EL
example.programlisting: <!-- Note: The US English translation of the x-has-x-friends key would look like the following: x-has-x-friends={0} has {1} friends. --> <h:outputText value="#{i18n.replace('x-has-x-friends', liferay.groupUser.fullName, friendsModel.dataModel.rowCount)}" />

sect1.title: liferay
sect1.para: This is a utility managed-bean that is designed to be kept in request scope. Its purpose is to introduce some Liferay-specific variables into the JSF EL. The reason why this is implemented as a managed-bean (and not as an ELResolver) is because it needs to kept in JSF 2 ViewScope.

sect1.title: liferay.companyId
sect1.para: The Liferay companyId primary key value associated with the community/organization portal page that the current portlet is placed upon.

example.title: EL Usage of liferay.companyId
example.programlisting: <h:outputText value="#{liferay.companyId} is the companyId associated with this set of Liferay Portal pages." />

sect1.title: liferay.documentLibraryURL
sect1.para: The absolute URL for the Liferay Document Library Struts action path prefix. The most common use case is to append the /get_file suffix and some additional request parameters in order to provide a hyperlink to a document in the Liferay Document Library. See the Liferay struts-config.xml file for a complete list of available suffixes.

example.title: EL Usage of liferay.documentLibraryURL
example.programlisting: <h:dataTable id="documents" value="#{documentModelBean.dataModel}" var="dlFileEntry"> <h:column> <f:facet name="head"> <h:outputText value="#{i18n['file-name']}" /> </f:facet> <h:outputLink target="_blank" value="#{liferay.documentLibraryURL}/get_file?p_l_id=#{liferay.themeDisplay.plid}&folderId=#{dlFileEntry.folderId}&name=#{dlFileEntry.name}"> <h:outputText value="#{dlFileEntry.title}" /> </h:outputLink> </h:column> </h:dataTable>

sect1.title: liferay.groupUser
sect1.para: The Liferay User that owns the Liferay community/organization portal page that the current portlet is placed upon.

example.title: EL Usage of liferay.groupUser
example.programlisting: <h:outputText value="The user named #{liferay.groupUser.fullName} owns this set of Liferay Portal pages." />

sect1.title: liferay.imageGalleryURL
sect1.para: The absolute URL for the Liferay Image Gallery Struts action path prefix. See the Liferay struts-config.xml file for a complete list of available suffixes.

sect1.title: liferay.imageURL
sect1.para: The absolute URL for the Liferay Image Servlet. Although this can be used to construct a URL that points a Liferay user's portrait/photo, for performance reasons, it is better to use the portraitURL EL variable instead.

sect1.title: liferay.layout
sect1.para: The Liferay Layout associated with the community/organization portal page that the current portlet is placed upon.

example.title: EL Usage of liferay.layout
example.programlisting: <h:outputText value="The name of this portal page is #{liferay.layout.name}" />

sect1.title: liferay.permissionChecker
sect1.para: The Liferay PermissionChecker associated with the current request and Liferay User.

sect1.title: liferay.portalURL
sect1.para: The absolute URL for the portal. For example: http://localhost:8080

sect1.title: liferay.portlet
sect1.para: The containing Liferay Portlet associated with the PortletRequest.

example.title: EL Usage of liferay.portlet
example.programlisting: <h:outputText value="The name of this portlet is #{liferay.portlet.displayName}" />

sect1.title: liferay.portraitURL
sect1.para: Designed to be called from the EL by passing a Liferay User or userId as an array index, returns the absolute URL to the user's portrait.

sect1.title: liferay.theme
sect1.para: The Liferay Theme associated with the Liferay Layout.

example.title: EL Usage of liferay.theme
example.programlisting: <h:outputText value="The name of the Liferay theme applied to this portal page is #{liferay.theme.name}" />

sect1.title: liferay.themeDisplay
sect1.para: The Liferay ThemeDisplay associated with the PortletRequest. Perhaps it is easier to think of the Liferay ThemeDisplay as a "display context" which provides access to a wealth of information including the current Company, User, Layout, Theme, PermissionChecker, and more.

sect1.title: liferay.themeImageURL
sect1.para: Designed to be called from the EL by passing a relative path to a theme image as an array index, returns the absolute URL to the theme image.

sect1.title: liferay.themeImagesURL
sect1.para: Returns the absolute URL for the image path associated with the current Liferay Theme. For example: http://localhost:8080/image/image_gallery.

sect1.title: liferay.user
sect1.para: the Liferay User associated with the PortletRequest.

sect1.title: liferay.userHasPortletPermission
sect1.para: Designed to be called from the EL by passing an action-key as an array index, returns a Boolean indicating whether or not the Liferay User associated with the PortletRequest has permission to execute the specified action-key on the current portlet. The action-key is typically defined in a Liferay resource-action-mapping XML file that defines the <portlet-resource/> and <model-resource/> permissions associated with a Liferay portlet. Please refer to the portal-impl/classes/resource-actions/messageboards.xml file in the Liferay Portal source code distribution for an example of how to write a Liferay resource-action-mapping XML file.
